p: Trypsin inhibitors are mainly present in seeds where its activity is found between 11,300 and 74,700 IU/g of seeds which varies according to the cultivar [ 19, 30]. Winged bean chymotrypsin inhibitors (WCI) are mainly present in tubers and a seed, its activity exceeds that of trypsin inhibitor, with 1 g of beans able to inhibit approximately 30 to 48 mg of chymotrypsin [ 35]. WCI are encoded by many genes and they can be distinguished as Bowman-brick-type inhibitors (three are identified till now) and Kunitz inhibitors KI (9 are identified till now) [ 35, 37]. Three new KI genes were isolated lately: WCI-3b, WCI-2 and WCI-5. WCI-5, expressed only in the seeds, was confirmed to have high proteinase inhibitor activity and inhibit the growth of larvae of Helicoverpa armigera, protecting the plant against this pest [ 38, 39].
